pros: Supportive and fun place to work.

review_title: Amazing organisation but do not work hard enough to keep their staff

pros: Great place, great benefits, inspiring
cons: very busy and sometimes overwhelming

review_title: Lovely institution, poor pay, truly awful management. Phony socialist principles.
pros: Fantastic building, working with some great individuals. Was an interesting industry to be involved in.
cons:
Unfortuntely there was almost entire exodus of designers from the Graphic Designer Studio. 

An unquestionable, unaccountable hierarchy led to continued top down decisions, lacking any compassion, creating a toxic environment, with an utterly egotistical approach towards members of this department.

Lack of personal development and ownership of work, prevents any real fulfilment working here. Far too much direction from marketing, who really lead the creative direction of the studio.

A great shame, it has the potential to be fantastic. Can only hope there will be change in this department, however it seems very unlikely. 

Stress caused was not worth time spent here in hindsight.

Was made to feel as if the studio was more of a school than a creative hub for an arts institution.

job_title: Cafe Kitchen Sales Assistant in London, England
pros:
-Amazing cafe managers and supervisors 
-People are generally really chill, interesting and friendly people to work with 
-Good pay (£9.95p/h)
-I was on a flexible work contract, managers were okay with me taking time off  as long as I told them in advance
-Free or reduced theatre tickets
-Staff room shared with whole building, including theatre professionals, actors and everyone to cleaners and bar staff, which made it a really inclusive place to work 
-could progress within the company, used to get lots of emails about internal positions and internships
cons:
generally rude customers, some periods of work were extremely busy
as I was on a flexible contract, hours could drastically change from week to week, sometimes 4 hours sometimes 24hours... but I think this is probably something I could have sorted with managers if I was vocal about it.

review_title: Brilliant place to work, but benefits not great.
job_title: Individual Giving Manager in London, England
pros:
Amazing culture 
Great communication across the organisation 
Feels like everyone is important 
Beautiful building (although not to everyone’s taste)
cons:
Pay isn’t great (know I could earn more if I went elsewhere) 
Benefits also not that great, holiday in year 1 is only 20 days which is the legal minimum 
Flexibility is coming in with WFH but not standard way if working, fixed working hours etc 
No death in service benefits

job_title: Customer Service Assistant in London, England
pros:
Access to the Theatres
A wonderful group of co-workers
cons:
A truly abysmal level of management. Every time a new person in middle management was hired there seemed to be a culture where they had to justify their position by instantly changing aspects of the Customer Service team's responsibilities with little consideration for how the theatre was run, or who would be enacting the actions on a day to day basis.
You will not be listened to. 
You will not be valued.

review_title: Do not work in a service department if you can help it.
job_title: Office Assistant in South Bank, England
pros:
Staff perks are genuinely amazing - free tickets, union benefits, classes, the works. 

The pay is pretty great in the Box Office department and the service staff are lovely for the most part.
cons:
The NT do good work and have a deserved positive reputation in the arts, but those in charge of the service side of things have some serious issues to work with as word is getting out about how badly staff are treated there. Before I go into my own experiences I've had friends who have been let go from casual bar roles for not giving enough availability (you hire casual staff, you get casual staff) and generally ignored, dehumanized or treated with general indifference. I think the NT feel like they can treat their staff how they like because people will line up to work for them given their reputation and their high pay.

My experience of working in the Box Office was a decent enough one at first - the job requires you to take in a lot of  changing information but this is honestly reflected in the pay so I have no problem with this.

What ruined the job for me was management, and multiple layers of it. Some supervisors were lovely and assisted with any inquires graciously while others seemed to be overly guarded and seemed to feel that assisting was somewhat beneath them. The real problems came when I wanted to discuss changing my contract from Part Time to Casual:

Part of the process involves handing notice for your current contract which I decided to do six weeks in advance. I had been discussing things with the operations manager when he got massively sick and was still absent once the date had passed. Eventually I asked him what was going on after the date had passed and I had effectively left the company. The email I got back was rude and dismissive and tried to blame me for the fact that he was unaware of the date I had left on my notice. I responded with proof that I had given a date and that his claim that I had asked to change my date was false and since then I have not had a single word from anyone in the box office.

Since that email the following has occurred:

-I have continued to be paid since leaving because the same operations manager had failed to send over the leaver form necessary to take me off payroll.
-Upon finding out that he neglected his responsibilities I made a formal complaint to the Box Office management about both continuing to be paid and the treatment mentioned above.
-I received a call from the HR department that only provided a weak apology despite my extensive grievances. They were far more focused on me paying the money back then addressing how I had been treated over the months.
-I emailed back stating that the time-frame for me to pay was unreasonable given the inconvenience imposed upon me. I asked for my complaints to be addressed by anyone at all. It's been a week and I've heard nothing.

If you work for the NT you can expect to be royally dismissed, generally condescended to and have management that disregard your concerns and send the message that they are totally above acknowledging doing any wrongdoing. The organizational skills are a shambles. As I said, the NT do great work but working for them has soured my opinion of them forever.

review_title: The most diverse fun place to work ever !

Its a fun place to work.
You can work in alot of different jobs.
It's by the Thames, nice in Summer ! 
You meet lots of contacts/friends.
People are generally very friendly.
cons: You have to work when other people are having fun ! Some jobs not well paid , like ushers, bar staff etc.
